_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Executive Summary



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

This facility is regulated under 29 CFR 1910.120, Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency

Response and 29 CFR 1920.38, Employee Emergency Plans and Fire Prevention Plans. Chemicals Incorporated Bay city Site fully complies with these regulations with employee training and written plans. Additionally, the facility closely communicates with local emergency response group.



2. Source and Substances Handled

Primary Activities: Organic Chemicals and specialty chemicals Toll Manufacturer



Use of Substances:

Propylene oxide: 45000 lbs (max), in Storage Tanks

3.I.a. Toxic Worst Case Scenario: Failure of tank holding 45000 lbs of propylene oxide with no

emergency response resulting in the complete release of contents over a 138 minute period. The

45000 pounds would form a vapor cloud with a toxic endpoint radius of 1.2 miles.

I.b. Toxic Alternative Scenario: 1" Hole in liquid space of propylene oxide tank, 42" liquid above hole,

releasing propylene oxide for 30 minutes at the rate of 203 lbs/min within a diked area with sumps

and sprinkler/deluge water available. The material released would form a vapor cloud with a toxic

endpoint radius of 0.2 miles.



Formaldehyde Solution (Max 37% in water): 45000 lbs in Storage Tank.

4.I.a. Toxic Worst Case Scenario: Failure of tank holding 45000 lbs of formaldehyde solution with no

emergency response resulting in the complete release of contents at the rate of 4.2 pounds per minute. The 45000 pounds would form a vapor cloud with a toxic endpoint radius of 0.8 miles.

I.b. Toxic Alternative Scenario: 1" Hole in liquid space of formaldehyde solution tank, 48" liquid above hole, releasing formaldehyde solution for 30 minutes at the rate of 1.83 lbs/min within a diked area with sumps and deluge water available. The material released would form a vapor cloud with a toxic

endpoint radius of 0.2 miles.



Propionitrile:  40037 lbs in d

rums in the covered warehouse.

5.I.a. Toxic Worst Case Scenario: Failure of a drum holding 320 lbs of propionitrile with no emergency response resulting in the complete release of contents at the rate of 0.226 pounds per minute. The 320 pounds would form a vapor cloud with a toxic endpoint radius of 1.0 miles.

I.b. Toxic Alternative Scenario: 1" Hole in liquid space of propionitrile drum, releasing propionitrile for 10 minutes at the rate of 0.194 lbs/min within building. The material released would form a vapor cloud with a toxic endpoint radius of 0.1 miles.



6. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

Chemicals Incorporated has made accident prevention the number one priority at the facility, and

accidental chemical release prevention is a major facet of the accident prevention activities at Chemicals

Incorporated. Key to the prevention program is comprehensive training of both operations and maintenance personnel.



7. Five Year Accident History Summary:

No Accidents involving RMP listed chemicals.



8. Emergency Response Program:

Chemicals Incorporated's Emergency Response Program is tailored to the varied processes inherent

to a small specialty chemical toll manufacturer. The plan rests on response trained operators and a 24 hour a day emergency coordinator along with two alternate coordinators to handle notifications and request for response from outside agencies such as Matagorda Count LEPC, Bay City Fire Department, and ambulance services.

Special equipment and personal protective gear is on hand for containing releases. Training of

employees is conducted to repair any possible leaking lines, tanks/containers. Additionally, the facility has 2.4 million gallon fire water reservoir and associated fire suppression/deluge system for fire fighting

service.



9. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Additional passive and active mitigation strategies, including automated deluge systems, are being

evaluate
d and installed for various equipment and tanks.
